newsitem.title: ITALY: ALPINE SKIING-NORWEGIAN TRIO IN ATTACKING FORM.
newsitem.headline: ALPINE SKIING-NORWEGIAN TRIO IN ATTACKING FORM.

text.p: Norway's attacking Vikings have won the first two men's races of the Alpine skiing world championships and questions are being asked.
Such as how do they do it and what exactly do they have that the other nations do not.
The answer appears to be a mixture of fortune, experiment -- and three very good skiers.
Atle Skaardal, 30-year-old winner of Monday's super-G, took the title last year as well and says he is not doing anything different this season.
"I'm too old to learn new things," said Skaardal, whose two second places in downhill World Cup races make him a medal candidate in Saturday's blue ribbon event as well.
Lasse Kjus, who came second in the super-G and led the combined event until a poor slalom second leg gave victory to compatriot Kjetil-Andre Aamodt, believed in luck.
"We are just that little bit older and maybe more experienced," he said on Friday. "You need a lot of luck to win races. Maybe we have been a bit lucky up until now."
Aamodt said nothing had changed. "We were good last year too," he said, although Norway have as many medals in two events as the men won in the entire 1996 championships.
In 1993 they won three golds and two silvers from four races, a tally they could well equal here, and again it was Aamodt, Kjus and Skaardal who did it.
However, luck aside, a new German coach brought in at the start of the season has also helped matters.
Martin Osswald worked formerly with Germany's world and Olympic giant slalom champion Markus Wasmeier and the German women juniors before the 1994 Olympics.

Jan Jensen, the president of the Norwegian Alpine skiing federation, said Osswald's arrival had been a great success and had brought a fresh approach to a coaching programme in danger of becoming stale.

"We are very satisfied with him. It has been very successful, he has brought new qualities into the Norwegian team," said Jensen. "At this level it is always a question of new creative ways of thinking. Every new way is positive."
"In the last four years we had followed the same lines but we have changed it according to his advice."
Audun Groenvold, a former ski jumper in his debut championships, said Osswald had a lot of experience and was making an impact more on the mental side.
"At this level the coach doesn't say so much, he isn't guiding us so much and we have to work a lot on our own. But he gives us small hints all the time," he said.
This season the Norwegians made a solid if unspectacular start with Aamodt finishing third in the first two races -- a giant slalom in Soelden and a slalom in Park City.
The first victory came in a slalom on December 1 when Tom Stiansen had his first World Cup win in Breckenridge.

Aamodt, who has had six podium finishes in total and leads the overall World Cup, won a giant slalom in Adelboden while Kjus, last year's World Cup champion, won a combined in Kitzbuehel to seal his comeback from illness.
Aamodt's combined win on Thursday night took his career medal tally to 11 and the 25-year-old admitted he had his sights on Marc Girardelli's record of 13.
"Yes, for sure it can be a goal for me. I have 11 medals now, two more to go. That'll be fun," he said.
The Norwegian women's team are far less successful with the promising racers of last season currently in disappointing form and without a podium finish.
Norway have never had a women's world or Olympic champion and 1993 world silver and bronze medallist Astrid Loedemel, who appeared to be the saviour some years ago, is injured.
